[h1]The best deal on Steam deal if you like coop campaigns[/h1]

This is one of the best deals in gaming ESPECIALLY if you like playing campaign coop.

This gives you six different full games in the [i]HALO[/i] universe including 1-4 and the two spin-off side stories, [i]HALO Reach[/i] and [i]HALO 3 ODST.[/i]

It's worth getting just for the classic 1-3 even aside from the spinoffs and [i]HALO 4[/i] and even those are worth getting on sale.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3591346330

The games are beautiful, the HALO 2 Remaster and HALO 4 really hold their own even against modern games, and all of them are substantially better in style than most games out there. All of the games in this collection have campaign coop which is why I got them.

[h1]Story[/h1]

All games in this collection have stories which are adequate at least, certainly better than the transgressive nonsense you'd get in a game like [i]Borderlands.[/i] If you play through the series in order, you will eventually end up with a very good story in the ending of [i]HALO 3[/i] which is probably the best story in the [i]HALO[/i] franchise and a MUCH better ending than the one in Mass Effect 3.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3604697835

Speaking of [i]Mass Effect,[/i] just as the [i[]Mass Effect: Legendary Edition[/i] would be my top recommendation for people like like single-player action RPGs, this collection is my top recommendation for people who like coop shooters, shooters with a campaign (single-player or otherwise) and probably several other categories I haven't thought of yet. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3605938451

In fact, I would even recommend this collection to people who usually play vehicle-combat games since there are enough of those (and enough options like unlimited ammo etc.) that this game is an above average experience for vehicle fans in comparison to other FPS type games. 

[h1]Quality of life improvements[/h1]

Because this is a collection of previously released content, you start with access to a lot of the quality of life features that you would normally unlock after finishing the game.

You can watch movies from the terminals even if you didn't find them from the extras section, you can use options like unlimited ammo that make the game easier as well as many other which make it harder, you can select any mission you want to play, etc. 

In other words, you already played through these games before somewhere else and want to replay a specific part with something you unlocked before, you can just jump in and do that here without having to jump through any hoops. 

To put it another way, this game starts out with all the options and content that you would have to unlock (or purchase as microtransactions) in a recent [i]Resident Evil[/i] game. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

While I personally don't like the direction they took with the story in [i]HALO 4,[/i] This would be worth getting even at full price for all the other games and even HALO 4 is a good game if you don't think about the story in relation to the previous (better) story of [i]HALO 3.[/i]

[h1]Troubleshooting[/h1]

The one significant bug which I encountered in this game was that on one mission in [/i]HALO 3, it started to slow down as if it had a memory leak.[/i] This was apparently a problem with the save file as the problem was replicated if I quit and reloaded the save but disappeared if I selected the same mission from mission select rather than using "resume".

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3606070861

In short, if your game slows down, select that mission from mission select rather than loading the save. Thankfully the quality of life feature that is mission select prevents the save problem from becoming a real issue.

A brilliant collection of some of the most solid and fun FPS games ever made even if certain parts of the older games are starting to show their age a little. See below for thoughts of the individual games

Halo CE: A Genre defining game that has stood the test of time even if certain parts of it are starting to show their age. Despite this the game has great and smooth controls that have stood the test for with a beautiful graphics update that brings it in line with the rest of the series (even if it sacrifices to amazing atmosphere and ambiance of certain levels), sadly the game had some parts that very got under my skin at times, the sometimes random difficulty spikes wild and all over the place checkpoint system and certain levels especially the 4, 8 and 9 level not being fun due to long stretches of the same level design coupled with sections, where the amount of enemies really starts to bog the pacing down to the point where you are unsure if its an endless spawn section your supposed to ignore or a finite number that you have to battle through.
Here's hoping that these are issues that are exclusive to the first game as i really enjoyed the game for the most part, it's just those sour points really did sour the experience. 

Halo 2: An improvement on the original with some minor frustrations that can sometimes mar the experience. Some levels can last too long and have frustrating, sometime unfair moments and the new Brute and flying enemies can really start driving you up the wall, but overall i enjoyed my time with this game. high recommendation. 

Halo 3: What a Finale, i can finally see why this was spoken about so much back in the day. a satisfying ending for the original series and a damn fine game. The only things holding it back are a small number of minor problem which thankfully can be ignored... all except the second to last level which can be a miserable, unpleasant slog with puts a dent on what is a well paced and fantastic campaign.

Halo 3 ODST: Halo 3 ODST is a bit of a mixed bag for me, on one hand it has amazing atmosphere, likeable character and an amazing detective like story where the more you play the more the story makes sense. on the other hand, navigating New Monbasa City becomes very tiring after awhile and the mission can sometimes have wild difficulty spike that catch you off guard. Nevertheless I still enjoyed my time with this game, still a high recommendation

Halo Reach: As Bungie's last game for the franchise, it's a sober but brilliantly made game that is as fun as the rest of the series, with all almost all the little tweaks and improvements mostly working to tell a brilliant story of humanity's most devastating defeats in the series. Without those little lighthearted moment present in the previous games however, this game becomes one the most depressing to play through, which i know is the point, but the other games in the series had a better balance of the dour and depressing contrasted with little lighthearted and hopeful moments 

Halo 4: AS 343 studios first FPS game in the Halo universe, it's not a bad first attempt but it sadly plays too safe and doesn't really do enough to stand out. the new enemies fluctuate between fun challenge and frustrating unfairness and the story while a good set up can be overwhelming, frantic and confusing at times saved only by the heartrendingly beautiful character moments between MC and Cortana. It's a shame then that 343 fumbled the other games stories after this as we could have had the start of something amazing. still a high recommendation.

Halo CE is basically a 2004 Gearbox port with minor improvements, yet still inferior to the Xbox original
Also do yourself a favor, and play Halo CE with original graphics. So much of the exceptional art style was lost in anniversary version. And though this game is 25 years old, it looks great given that Bungie devised the unique art style around the Xbox' technical abilities.

Halo 2 is slighlty fixed Vista port of the original game, and still has bugs that originated 5 years ago.
In contrast with Halo CE, Halo 2 is better in remastered form, as the original design envisioned by Bungie for this game was never realized in the original due to Xbox technical limitations. Bungie wanted to make shadows a viable part of the level design (Doom 3 was a thing back then), yet the old Xbox could not handle this, hence the game looked bland. The remastered version adds that needed depth to the level design, as well as is way more restrained in its improvements compared to Halo CE remaster. 
One thing that taints the experience with Halo 2 remaster is bugs. sometimes checkpoints do not register, there is annoying bug with random grenade throws on standard gamepad layout (I swapped LT with LB for grenades). Sometimes switching visuals in between cutscenes crashes the game. All those bugs are well known, but 343 is too busy ruining the series so there are no fixes 5+ years later.

Halo 3 seems to be ok, thanks to it being X360 game and seemingly requiring less effort to run properly. So its basically a PC port of that game, and it looks the way it did when I first played it on 720p TV. And that looks great. Bungie might sometimes suck at level design and console-ish gameplay, but their art style during OG Halo years was top notch.

There is also a decent ODST spin-off here that adds some stuff to original story with solid gameplay, as well as Reach, which is a mixed bag given its innovations that now are associated with 343's games.. And Halo 4, not that anyone should care about it since Master Chief's story was done with Halo 3, and none of 343's poorly witten fanfics cannot change it.

I am stuggling to rate MCC positive, given it still has bugs that by now are old enough to go to school, and the fact that the only *real* added value is Halo 2 Anniversary, but if you want to play the OG Halo trilogy without trying abondonware (like Gearbox'  Halo CE build they published a year after PC port's release), this is the simplest way. But be prepapred for a rough ride, especially for Halo 2.

Anyway first thing I immediately noticed: The whole "remastered" versions is absolutely awful to look at, Ive never cared much for the Halo series, but even I could tell the original vision/look was completely ruined in the "enhanced" version, random generic sci-fi "greeble" everywhere for all textures, bright lighting that doesnt even fit original, and characters that now blend into background, a waste of disk space and should have been optional to download.

Now for the game: Maybe its just first original game not quite having found its footing yet, classic stuff for old games... But the gameplay of fighting in exact looking corridors for the first 45 minutes was not very engaging or fun, I figured it was maybe just because it was a "tutorial", but I quickly learned later gameplay was no different, its just constantly fighting in some huge empty "open world", walking slowly/driving to another outpost/tower thing, and fighting enemies from dropships over and over until I realized I could just leave the area at any moment, and went on to next outpost which was exactly the same for 3-4 more times.

Maybe I just didnt "get it", but this was just incredibly unfun, I tried playing the first 45 mintues of Reach too which was just more of the same, drive some vehicle in a huge empty valley with an empty building here and there, then fighting gunship enemies, and moving on to next spot, I cant imagine this changes much later game based on previous experience.

Im sure "it gets better" later but I dont think I have it in me to play more, and I have zero interest in multiplayer either so im judging purely by singleplayer, which so far was not a very enjoyable experience at all.

If you like driving through massive open valleys, defending big towers from endless waves of dropships and shooting enemies in dark samey-looking sci fi corridors over and over, then this is for you, if not then I dont know...
